title: Introduction
text:
1. Why a BtM?

Problem to solve: Existing commercial solutions were expensive and did not fully meet our specific needs. They offered limited flexibility and closed architectures, which constrained our research applications.
Our approach: Free/Libre and Open Source Development
We chose to develop our own solution using open hardware and open software.
Advantages include:

Lower cost
Transparency and reproducibility
Full adaptability to specific research needs
Collaborative improvement and customization





2. What is a BtM?
The BtM (Bryolichen Temperature Moisture board) is:

A datalogger with:

A temperature/humidity sensor for ambient conditions
8 activity detection channels based on soil or organism water content



How do we measure “activity”?

Water content–activity correlation: Biological activity is closely related to water content in soils and substrates.
Water content = Conductance: By measuring electrical conductance, we estimate water content, which serves as a proxy for activity.
BtM includes both software and hardware components, all completely open and free.


Hardware Demonstration

We will show the BtM device in both field and laboratory setups.
(Include photo of the open BtM case)



Software Demonstration

We will explore the code used to operate and analyze data with the BtM.

For this first method, we are going to use a protoboard with a set of resistors (like the one in the image).



Detail of BtM connection to the resistors



⚠️ IMPORTANT: Make sure you know the value of the resistors. If not, you can check the colors of the resistors and use this calculator.







BtM calibration using Method B


This method simulates precipitation.

⚠️ IMPORTANT: A spray that emits known quantities of water is required. Ideally, distilled (or low mineralization) water should be used.


We start from a very dry sample.
We wet the sample with the spray once.
Measure (time and resistance)
If the sample has not saturated, repeat from 2.
If the sample saturates (constant resistance), we stop.

title: Requirements for the Workshop
text:
Requirements for the Workshop
To ensure a smooth and productive experience during the workshop, please prepare the following items in advance:

Computer: Please bring a laptop (We recommend Linux, but can be done in Windows or Mac). Make sure your device has at least one USB port and administrative privileges to install software.
Arduino IDE: We will be using the Arduino 2 IDE. Please install it in advance by following these steps:

Go to the official Arduino IDE 2 download page
Download the installer for your operating system.
Follow the installation instructions specific to your platform
Make sure the IDE launches correctly after installation. If you encounter any issues, consult the installation guide provided by Arduino.
Copy the libraries folder in:

Documents/Arduino/ (Windows)
~/Arduino/ (Linux & Mac)


Code: Please download the workshop repository in advance in using one of the following formats: ZIP File or GitHub Link. Although the original BtM code can also be used.

Make sure you get the contents (or extract them if you downloaded the ZIP) and browse the folder to verify that everything was downloaded correctly. Remember the path of this directory.


If you have any questions or need technical support before the workshop, feel free to contact us at: angel.lareo@uam.es / maria.leomontes@gmail.com

title: Hardware details
text:
How conductance is measured:
Measures are based on Ohm’s Law. Ohm’s Law relates voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R):
\[
V = I \cdot R
\] Although measures are taken as resistance values (in \(\ohm\)), it is commonly plotted as conductance values. There is a direct inverse relation between impedance (R) and conductance (G): \[    
G = \frac{1}{R}
\]

Voltage Divider


import {Inputs, md} from "@observablehq/inputs"

viewof Vin = Inputs.range([0, 10], {
  label: "Input Voltage (V)",
  value: 5,
  step: 0.1
})

viewof R1 = Inputs.range([100, 10000], {
  label: "Resistance R1 (Ω)",
  value: 1000,
  step: 100
})

viewof R2 = Inputs.range([100, 10000], {
  label: "Resistance R2 (Ω)",
  value: 1000,
  step: 100
})

md`**🔋 Output Voltage (Vout):** \`${(Vin * R2 / (R1 + R2)).toFixed(2)} V\``

BtM saves data in 11 columns in a .csv file to the Micro SD card
To obtain the CSV file, SD card has to be physically extracted




BtM output in .csv format



Date/Time
Temperature (ºC)
Relative Humidity (%)
8 impedance columns with the value of each activity channel (ohm)

low values (< 100) indicate the sample is moist, high values (> 10,000) indicate the sample is wet (these values are resistance-dependent).
